paragraphs.text: Last week I published my first piece on Medium and watched as, for an hour and a half, 1 person viewed (and failed to finish) my piece. I went to sleep, saying to myself “I suck”.

virtuals.subtitle: Hack those words out, one at a time. Groom later. Today, let’s just try!

paragraphs.text: Wonderfully said, Joely. It’s also hard to remember back to the struggle when we have the final product. My hope in getting used to sucking is to always remember what it feels like. I don’t want selective amnesia of the process, because then I wouldn’t be able to relate to others (read: everyone) going through the same process. Moreover, when I go to…
paragraphs.name: de2d

89069e3f1452.title: I love that you posted this feeling that we all have, but is hard to talk about.

paragraphs.text: I love that you posted this feeling that we all have, but is hard to talk about. I’m trying to start a new writing project and every time I get rolling I read back over it I realize that it is just not as good as I want it to be. And yet, I keep trying because it will get better. I think the most important thing as a writer is to just keep writing…
paragraphs.name: 665b

5f9b98021f8.title: Lottie, what a beautiful personal experience to relate.

paragraphs.text: Lottie, what a beautiful personal experience to relate. Welcome to Medium, welcome to sucking, and please, please, keep telling stories!
paragraphs.name: f0d3

7e5b27aa2420.title: Absolutely, Alex. Thanks for reading and good luck with sucking!

paragraphs.text: Absolutely, Alex. Thanks for reading and good luck with sucking!

e018d53f8c4b.title: I’m glad you felt some truth and support here, Amanda.

paragraphs.text: I’m glad you felt some truth and support here, Amanda. I’ve recently encountered the experience of reading back over my work (particularly work I felt good about) and laying my head on the table afterwards, wondering how I’ll ever make the leap to “greatness.” You’ve revealed the secret ingredient: keep writing. I wish you all the best in your journey of both sucking and greatness!
paragraphs.name: 21de

689e994ee0dc.title: If you don’t suck at something or other, then you aren’t growing.

paragraphs.text: If you don’t suck at something or other, then you aren’t growing. It’s nice, attractive, to live in a safe world, never really venturing forth. I often think of the phrase “the perfect is the enemy of the good.” Venture on….and be imperfect. As a friend once told me, “You have permission to do <whatever it is> badly.”
paragraphs.name: 0a95

paragraphs.text: Beautiful, Julia. Thanks for sharing!
paragraphs.name: c585

aac857a54455.title: Thank you for sharing this story, John.

paragraphs.text: Thank you for sharing this story, John. It’s amazing how our perceptions of ourselves can be so different from how others perceive us. It’s worth learning to quite down that little inner critic. I’m more convinced each day she doesn’t actually know what she’s talking about!
paragraphs.name: 170a

paragraphs.text: Happy sucking!
paragraphs.name: 11a0

paragraphs.text: A good point, Jackson. And hopefully we always feel we can improve in the things we’re passionate about. How boring it would be to feel like we’ve reached the end of our growth and development!
paragraphs.name: 2e64

paragraphs.text: Ah, a midday Prosecco nap. Surely that she be joyous? :) Sucking at first is good because you have a huge amount of scope for improvement. Somebody will always be there to kick your butt but at least you have something to aim for.

paragraphs.text: Getting Used to Sucking
paragraphs.name: 04b7

paragraphs.text: Part of being a creative is getting used to sucking. I was going to write a nice, fancy intro for this, but there you…

Steven: don’t give up! Never give up! You’re absolutely right: it’s about doing and not doing it perfectly. Write about what strikes passion into your heart. Some articles fly and others don’t. The pieces I’m most proud of got the least amount of attention. Welcome to the unpredictable, sometimes crazy-making roller coaster that is publishing on…
paragraphs.name: 8b31

7dc0aaa95c190ebf3cf00528d2b63b56.title: I love that you posted this feeling that we all have, but is hard to talk about.

paragraphs.text: Part of being a creative is getting used to sucking. I was going to write a nice, fancy intro for this, but there you have it: today I suck at writing fancy intros.

Don’t quit. Never quit. Instead, just get used to sucking. I’m no New York Time’s Bestselling author, but even if I were, I have a hunch these feelings — the ups and downs of creating — will never go away. A nice award or lots of money won’t change my internal dialogue. Only I can do that. Only I can hold myself back from continuing to pursue my dreams.
paragraphs.name: 03ea

paragraphs.text: Please, correct me if I’m wrong — I’d love to hear from those of you who feel amazing at what you do, always, and then I’ll cry myself to sleep in a midday Prosecco nap. However, for the majority of us, our main goal shouldn’t be perfection. It should only be to keep trying and to keep recognizing the ways in which we judge ourselves. We don’t actually know if our stuff sucks — we only think it does. And if you’re working from home with only your own thoughts most of the day, those thoughts can be destructive and seduce you into doing the last thing you should ever do: quit.
paragraphs.name: 976f
